==Meta-ethics==
 
==Meta-ethics==
 
{{Main|Meta-ethics}}
 
{{Main|Meta-ethics}}
−
Meta-ethics is the branch of ethics that seeks to understand the nature of ethical properties, ethical statements, attitudes, and judgments. Meta-ethics as a discipline gained attention with [[George Edward Moore|G.E. Moore]]'s famous work ''[[Principia Ethica]]'' from 1903 in which Moore first addressed what he referred to as ''the [[naturalistic fallacy]]''. Moore's rebuttal of naturalistic ethics, in his [[Open Question Argument]] rekindled an interest within the analytic branch of western philosophy. There was increased interest in second order questions about ethics; specifically the [[semantics]], [[epistemology]], and [[ontology]] of ethics. Earlier, the Scottish philosopher [[David Hume]] had outlined a sceptical view with his emphasis on the difference between [[Is-ought problem|facts and values]].
+
Meta-ethics is the branch of ethics that seeks to understand the nature of ethical properties, ethical statements, attitudes, and judgments. Meta-ethics as a discipline gained attention with [[George Edward Moore|G.E. Moore]]'s famous work ''[[Principia Ethica]]'' from 1903 in which Moore first addressed what he referred to as ''the [[naturalistic fallacy]]''. Moore's rebuttal of naturalistic ethics, in his [[Open Question Argument]], rekindled an interest in second order questions about ethics. Philosophers looked again at the [[semantics]], [[epistemology]], and [[ontology]] of ethics. Earlier, the Scottish philosopher [[David Hume]] had outlined a sceptical view with his emphasis on the difference between [[Is-ought problem|facts and values]].
     
The epistemology and semantics of ethics divides into [[Cognitivism (ethics)|cognitivism]] and [[Non-cognitivism (ethics)|non-cognitivism]]; a distinction that is often perceived as equivalent to that between [[Descriptivism|descriptivists]] and non-descriptivists. Non-cognitivism is the claim that ethical judgements are nether true nor false, that there are not facts in virtue of which we can accept them or reject them<ref>http://www.iep.utm.edu/non-cogn/</ref>. Cognitivism can then be seen as the claim that ethics is essentially concerned with judgments of the same kind as knowledge judgments; namely, about matters of fact.
 
The epistemology and semantics of ethics divides into [[Cognitivism (ethics)|cognitivism]] and [[Non-cognitivism (ethics)|non-cognitivism]]; a distinction that is often perceived as equivalent to that between [[Descriptivism|descriptivists]] and non-descriptivists. Non-cognitivism is the claim that ethical judgements are nether true nor false, that there are not facts in virtue of which we can accept them or reject them<ref>http://www.iep.utm.edu/non-cogn/</ref>. Cognitivism can then be seen as the claim that ethics is essentially concerned with judgments of the same kind as knowledge judgments; namely, about matters of fact.
